He's been damaged by the bathroom bill.
Staying pat. At this point, incumbancy should be reflective of the polls. McCrory is still behind.  Nuff said.

Up 30%. I'm not sure why I've been so low relative to the consensus. I'm over-compensating somewhat for scoring purposes. Who knows what the polling really suggests, but I doubt the fundamentals of the race warrant something too far removed from a toss-up.

When I see left polls giving a R in the lead I am inclined to think that he might be actually in the lead. We need to also take into account the bad impression supporters of the democratic party made by attacking the NC county GOP office, setting the place on fire and drawing NAZI symbols on the building. The incident was largely unreported by the mainstream media and some uncertain voters may step to the GOP side as they see the unfair treatment of republicans.

The race is close, but McCrory appears in the lead in the latest polls.

It certainly looks like he's the underdog, but the polls aren't as unequivocal about this as the consensus. Of the last 5 polls (since October 14): 
McCrory is up by 1 or 2 points in 2 of them 
Cooper is up by 2 points in 2 of them
Cooper is up by 6 points in 1 of them  This strikes me as consistent with a 2 point lead for Cooper, which makes him the favorite, but not overwhelmingly so.
The polls have a dead heat at McCory down by 0.5%. Turn-Out is the key.
Polls favour Cooper, but McCrory's trend is very strongly upward.
McCrory has picked up several points, to within 3% of Cooper: http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/governor/nc/north_carolina_governor_mccrory_vs_cooper-4096.html
RCP Polling now averages with Cooper (D) four points ahead. Margin of error is about 3.5% though. I'm not sure what will happen with turnout here.

Fourth ... recent flooding from Mathew. Maybe this isn't fair, but the level of destruction and seemingly slow pace of restoration will be the nail in the coffin. McCrory gets the blame.

http://www.charlotteobserver.com/news/politics-government/election/article101085787.html "Real Clear Politics shows Cooper with an average lead of 6 points in recent polls." Myers and other critics say McCrory began shifting right in 2012 in his second campaign for governor, when he advocated policies such as “fracking” and spoke on behalf of Americans for Prosperity, a group tied to the libertarian Koch brothers. Democratic candidate Walter Dalton said McCrory had embraced “the tea party agenda.” "While cutting taxes and rolling back regulations, they [the state's General Assembly]  blocked Medicaid expansion, cut jobless benefits, eliminated the earned income tax credit and repealed the Racial Justice Act that had put a de facto moratorium on executions. Before HB2, they approved controversial measures on abortion, guns and voting. McCrory has signed 727 bills. Critics say it was the legislature, not him, who set the agenda.
. . . 
"Though the governor vetoed six bills, lawmakers overrode four. One was Senate GOP Leader Phil Berger’s measure allowing magistrates to recuse themselves on religious grounds from performing same-sex marriages.
. . . 
"“the ‘Carolina Comeback’ has been swallowed by HB2.”
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  McCrory (R) had a reputation as a moderate and had been voted into office with the support of significant numbers of Democrats and independents.  Since passage of HB2, the "bathroom law", however, people have taken note of his many conservative measures involving abortion, guns, fracking, voting and taxes, and that he seems to have embraced a Koch brothers-Tea Party agenda.  This has caused him to lose the support of the independents and Democrats who had supported him in past elections.

Haven't been on in a while and a lot has happened so I'm making some changes. Just by looking off of real clear politics, the average of polls across the country has cooper up by 6 points. I lower my percentage by 20%.
The court decision invalidating voter ID laws will result in increased voting by illegal immigrants. That puts McCrory at a disadvantage.

http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/elections/2016/08/31/us-high-court-refuses-to-reinstate-north-carolina-voter-id/89666518/ The Supreme Court just voted 4-4 on a case impacting voter ID laws in NC.  Because of the SCOTUS tie, a lower court decision stands.   "The justices rejected the request by Republican Gov. Pat McCrory to reinstate the law that the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 4th Circuit said last month "disproportionately affected African Americans'' in North Carolina. "The new provisions target African Americans with almost surgical precision,'' the appellate court panel said. "They constitute inapt remedies ... and impose cures for problems that did not exist.'' "As a result of the Supreme Court action, early voting in this year's presidential election will extend for 17 days and voters will not have to present photo identification at their assigned precincts. . . .  
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  This ruling has been greeted with cheers by Democrats and boos by Republicans.   It was a blow to McCrory and his agenda.  Adjusting forecast from 23% to 21%.

It doesn't get more of a toss-up than this. Polling is dead-even and all of the qualitative sites have it as a toss-up. Markets give a slight edge to Cooper. McCrory does have an incumbency advantage. However, there is also a Libertarian in the race, which may pull some votes away from him. North Carolina is tight for the presidential race as well -- perhaps this has some coattails from that race. That would be consistent with the last two elections, when Obama won the state in '08 and a Democrat took the governor's race, while Romney won it in 2012 and McCrory won. It's hard to push this race past 50/50 for now. We need more data. Until then, I'll keep it split.

I am not a Trump or Hillary supporter, so take this as a non-partisan objective viewpoint: I am all in on a Trump easy victory, and so am answering these questions with that lens.
GOP incumbent will be damaged by Trump in a close election.
HB2 and Coal Ash have hurt him badly. But core republicans might stick with him.

North Carolina is a fairly conservative state that has featured competitive elections lately.  It may be in the toss-up column for 2016.  Even if Hillary Clinton wins the state this fall, it is unlikely that she will have long coattails.  Voters in NC may even want to provide a check at the state level for what they do presidentially.

In the United States, out of the 50 governors, 39 are incumbents and have held office since at least 2014; many have held office since 2009-2011. In Congress, incumbents have a higher probability of winning reelection. In November of 2004, 401 of the 435 sitting members of the U.S. House of Representatives sought reelection. Of those 401, all but five were reelected. In other words, incumbents seeking reelection to the House had a better than 99% success rate. In the U.S. Senate, only one incumbent seeking reelection was defeated. Twenty-five of twenty-six (96%) were reelected. I assume this can translate to governors. With this, I make my baseline estimate at 78%. A recent poll states that there is a dead even tie in North Carolina between Pat McCrory (41%) and Roy Cooper (41%). This makes things very difficult to predict. North Carolina is a swing state and is divided by Republicans and Democrats. Because of this I lower my estimate by 20%. In this state, it seems that the incumbency effect will not nearly be as strong. 58%. http://www.publicpolicypolling.com/pdf/2015/PPP_Release_NC_52416.pdf Why would Pat McCrory be re-elected? According to this article, as of May 26, Pat McCrory has a 5 point lead, 45% to 40% against Cooper despite the recent outrage for the HB2. This is subject to change but with this I increase my probability slightly (2-4%) to 62%. http://www.breitbart.com/big-government/2016/05/26/transgender-north-carolina-mccrory-15-points/ Why would he not be re-elected? Recently, Pat McCrory has signed House Bill 2 which is also called Public Facilities Privacy and Security Act which mandates that people can only go into bathrooms that correspond with the gender on their birth certificate. This affects many gay, lesbian, transgender, and intersex people. In North Carolina, it has sparked public outrage, caused music performers to cancel shows, and motivated certain companies to pull out investments. The Center for American Progress estimates that this will cost the state half a billion dollars in lost private sector economic activity. The United States Department of Justice has filed two lawsuits against McCrory stating that this violates federal civil rights laws. This will obviously make democratic voters vote against him but because North Carolina has a very even Republican and Democratic split, I don’t see this lowering his chances by too much.
The state trends conservative outside its larger cities, and the economic fallout from the rushed "bathroom crisis" will have passed from voter memory.
negative backwash from party leader, unpopular policy decisions, tension with business community, blackballed by sports venues
The prediction markets are at 55%; Weighted average (2 to 1) gives me 63%

in the last 115 years of North Carolina Governorship only 15 years has been occupied by a Republican (13%).  "6.5 million people registered to vote in NC, some 30.5 percent are Republicans. Democrats make up 40.8 percent, Libertarians account for about half a percent, and unaffiliated voters make up the remaining 28 percent" https://www.carolinajournal.com/opinion-article/how-republican-is-north-carolina/ "While North Carolina is experiencing a huge spike in the number of voters who don’t identify with either party, Gallup routinely finds it to be among the most politically balanced in the country, most recently putting Republicans at 41.9 percent of the population and Democrats at 41.3 percent" http://www.governing.com/topics/politics/gov-north-carolina-southern-progressivism.html Analysis:  Gallup shows North Carolina is evenly split when it comes to political affiliation.  Looking at the recent laws passed in NC indicates religion may be the motivating factor.  NC passed the religious freedom law and the bathroom law.  These laws obviously contradict a national progressive ideology.  North Carolinians seem to be legislating from the pulpit, "Joey Deese told Rock Hill City Council on Monday that the city needs to take a “biblical stand” on the issue" http://www.charlotteobserver.com/living/religion/article77770417.html    So for now as long as the issues in North Carolina attack religious beliefs/ideology the republican incumbent has the edge.

The fact that NC is a historically blue state when it comes to the governorship, there is a strong opponent who is already statistically tied in nearly every poll, the recent bathroom controversy, and economic numbers all factored in. Strong State GDP growth, but poor per capita growth, meaning that economic factors will not play in incumbent's favor. His approval rating is taking a hit after HB2. That being said, bathroom law may encourage social conservatives to turnout in slightly higher numbers than social liberals as a slight majority oppose laws like HB2, but voters who DO support it, strongly support it. Will be extremely close, but I think Cooper will win.

His Democratic challenger, Attorney General Roy Cooper, has name recognition and has shown himself electable. THese "accomplishements" are taken from Copper's website, so take with a grain of salt, nevertheless..... Increased DNA testing of crime scene evidence to identify the guilty and clear the innocent, and inclusion of all felons and certain arrestees in the state's database of convicted offenders, resulting in a record number of hits to help solve crimes.
Tougher sentences for child predators and pornographers and more tools to help law enforcement track down offenders including establishing the first SBI Computer Crimes Unit.
Mandates to require sex offenders to report where they live, plus email notifications and a free app to alert you to offenders in your community.
Taking on tough cases, including resolving the Duke Lacrosse case and investigating and prosecuting public corruption involving sheriffs, district attorneys, state legislators, and other elected officials.
Fighting school violence by training law enforcement in rapid deployment and helping schools plan for emergencies such as school shootings.
Helping prevent crime through tutoring and mentoring efforts to keep kids out of a life of crime and gangs.
Winning a landmark national settlement to reform mortgages and prevent foreclosure abuses, including more than $300 million in help for NC homeowners.
Directing consumer funds to prescription drug initiatives for those who cannot afford their medications. Cooper has out-raised McCrory 14 months in a row. Republicans say there's still time for McCrory to recover and improve his image as a jobs governor. REALLY?!?!?! 
How can you be a "jobs governor" if $Ms and companies are abandoning the state??
The business community can't/won't encourage ideological behavior that attacks their bottom line. That support along with Cooper's general popularity make it a tough road.

From 1995 to 2009, McCrory served as mayor of Charlotte. During that time, he was seen as a moderate conservative and enjoyed bipartisan support. During the 2012 race, he campaigned as a strict conservative, enjoying support from the tea party movement and other far-right groups. McCrory, however, disputed criticism that he had shifted his views. 
An analysis of Republican governors by Nate Silver of the New York Times in April 2013 ranked McCrory as the ninth most conservative governor in the country.
https://ballotpedia.org/Pat_McCrory
 https://www.patmccrory.com/2016/06/02/attorney-general-reverses-course-federal-litigation/
On the Friday before Memorial Day weekend, Attorney General Roy Cooper told a federal court that his office intends to appear on behalf of the State of North Carolina in the lawsuit involving the U.S. Department of Justice. This quiet reversal of the Attorney General’s public position comes after his office repeatedly indicated he would not defend the state in any lawsuit involving a common-sense law to protect privacy in bathrooms, locker rooms and shower facilities.
His filings also indicate that his office engaged in conversations with the U.S. Department of Justice prior to entering the case. The Attorney General reversed his position without consulting any of the defendants in the lawsuit, and he did not make any public announcement that he had entered the case to represent the State of North Carolina.
Both the Attorney General and his campaign made public statements as recently as yesterday that undermine the state’s position and contradict the legal filings by his office. Therefore, in light of the conflicting statements by the Attorney General, Governor McCrory filed notice in federal court that his administration intends to represent and defend the State of North Carolina in its lawsuit.
(It seems that the Gov. doubt the tenacity with which the AG will defend the states position, so there is a fight over who has standing, with the Gov.Office insisting that THEY will represent the state in this matter.) Governor Pat McCrory has maintained that HB2 is a commonsense bill, meant to preserve the safety and privacy of individuals in their most vulnerable and private of places – the bathrooms and shower rooms around North Carolina. Attorney General Roy Cooper, Democrat challenger for the Governor’s seat, has towed the social justice warrior line and declared the bill “anti-transgender,” refusing to do his job and defend the state against the lawsuit brought by Obama’s Department of (social) Justice.
On Thursday, Governor McCrory’s office revealed that AG Cooper had quietly filed with federal court his office’s intentions to defend the state against the federal lawsuit.
The filing came the Friday before Memorial Day weekend, with little fanfare.
While Cooper’s office insists the filing was just an admission that the state deserves a defense, and a request for an extension of time to find representation, McCrory spokesman, Ricky Diaz, is calling for Cooper to resign, based on conflicting statements and neglecting his duties, as AG.
http://www.redstate.com/sweetie15/2016/06/03/nc-gov.-pat-mccrorys-spokesman-calls-attorney-general-roy-cooper-resign-failure-job/
Inclination may be yes, but economic blow back might be hard to ignore.
